node.text: Airbnb's $100 billion business model is built on strangers trusting each other. When things go horribly wrong, the company's secretive safety team steps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families and prevent PR disasters. (via @businessweek)

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text:
Two of the world's wealthiest individuals will attempt to fly into space just nine days apart.

Here's how their space trips compare. (via @quicktake)

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.text:
Plant-based meat used to mean burgers and sausages. Not anymore.

Using techniques from 3D printing to specially cultivated mushrooms, these companies are at the forefront of the next generation of alternative meats: whole cuts. (via @quicktake)

node.text:

Tap the link in bio for more pictures. (via @quicktake)

node.text:
Taiwan is becoming a bigger issue between the world's two biggest superpowers. Taipei — a U.S. ally — and Beijing have avoided war for more than seven decades, but that balance is getting harder to maintain as China becomes more assertive in its desire for reunification.

Watch the full video at the link in bio to understand why analysts say Taiwan's status is "the most likely issue to draw China and the U.S. into a direct military conflict."

node.title: Why the Biggest U.S.-China Issue Is About Taiwan

node.text:
Shotgun houses are as much a hallmark of New Orleans as brass bands or beignets. Here's a short history of these famous U.S. homes built without hallways.

Explore more iconic home designs that shaped global cities in this @citylab series: bloomberg.com/home-design-history

node.text: Airbnb's $100 billion business model is built on strangers trusting each other. When things go horribly wrong, the company's secretive safety team steps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families and prevent PR disasters. (via @businessweek)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 31, 2021. May be an image of bottle and text.

node.text:
Some French winemakers are going back to Champagne’s roots. Long before the monk Dom Perignon—so the legend goes—figured out how to put bubbles in the bottle, still wines were the region’s norm.

Now these still wines, or “coteaux Champenois,” are becoming more common, thanks to climate change. And producers in the region are increasingly making wines without the trademark bubbles.

Some are delicious, others not so much — and they aren’t cheap. Tap the link in our bio for some recommendations.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 31, 2021. May be an image of 5 people, people standing, sunglasses and text that says 'Want to know where inflation is heading? Watch these 35 metrics BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
A year ago, the Covid-19 pandemic crushed prices in many parts of the U.S. economy. As expected, that has created inflation 12 months on as the economy reopens and rebounds.
 
The market seems to believe that a resurgence of the pandemic will rein in inflation before it grows out of control. No one disputes that inflation has arrived, writes @bloombergopinion’s John Authers. The question is where it’s heading.

35 metrics hold the clues, covering everything from wages to the bond market. We’re calling them Authers’ Indicators — tap the link in bio to see more.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Are Covid- 19 shots working? Here's what the real world tells us Bloomberg'.

node.text:
With Covid-19 shots in billions of arms by now, evidence is emerging of how well they work outside the lab.
 
Vaccines authorized for emergency use have successfully subdued epidemics in nations where at least half of the population is fully immunized. But as more-transmissible variants spread, driving fresh outbreaks and an increase in breakthrough infections, some authorities are recommending immunized people wear face-masks indoors for extra protection.

Tap the link in bio for our free-to-read Q&A on how different shots compare in the real world, emerging evidence about variants and caveats to look out for in the data.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 31, 2021. May be an image of skyscraper and text that says 'Singapore will sacrifice Covid Zero status foranambitiousreopening an Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Singapore is aiming for a feat no country has achieved so far: reopen to the world and emerge from the pandemic with a death toll still in the double digits.

In a plan laid out by officials this week, the tiny city-state that relies on being globally connected is eyeing the resumption of some international travel by September. To do that, it’s trying to snuff out an outbreak driven by the delta variant and reach a vaccination level -- 80% -- that few countries have achieved, but which the government says will put the country in a position where it can live with the virus without carnage.

While the promise of easier travel for the vaccinated sparked jubilation in Singapore, the question remains if its leaders will actually take what will be a leap of faith for a nation where even one locally-transmitted Covid case makes the front page. Read more in our link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Jeff Bezos's wealth falls $13.5 billionas Amazon's earnings disappoint Bloomberg Bloombh Wealth'.

node.text:
Amazon's weaker-than-expected second-quarter results sent its founder’s fortune tumbling. 

A drop in the company’s share price knocked $13.5 billion off Jeff Bezos’s net worth on Friday morning, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. It's the first time the retailer has missed a sales estimate since 2018. 

Don't worry though — Bezos still has $193.6 billion in the bank. More at the link in our bio.

📷: Mandel Ngan/AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Business on July 30, 2021 tagging @bloombergequality. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Focus on athletes' mental health raises questions about social media Bloomberg TOKYO2020'.

node.text:
The growing focus on mental health at the Olympic Games is bringing attention to the pitfalls and benefits of social media use by top athletes.
 
South Korean archer An San, who won three gold medals at #Tokyo2020, became the target of misogynist attacks online from people who criticized her short hairstyle as being "feminist." Japanese mixed-doubles table tennis winner Jun Mizutani said in a now-deleted Twitter post after his victory over China that he was getting anonymous death threats. The list goes on.

While elite sportspeople have long used the likes of Instagram and TikTok to connect with fans and expand their sphere of influence, Olympic athletes are increasingly speaking out about the effects of online abuse — with some deciding to leave social platforms altogether. Full story at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'How a poor student turned turnedtechtycoon tech became South Korea's richest person Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
Brian Kim, the founder of South Korean messaging giant Kakao, has seen his fortune jump by more than $6 billion this year, propelling him to the top of the country’s wealth ranking.

Kakao shares rose 90% in 2021 alone, and Kim is now worth $13.5 billion, unseating Samsung heir Jay Y. Lee who has a net worth of $12.3 billion.

It's an example of how self-made technology entrepreneurs are climbing the rich list in South Korea, passing members of families that control the country's decades-old conglomerates. Click the link in bio to read more about the Kim's meteoric rise.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Scarlett Johansson sues Disney over "Black Widow" CON ERNATIO Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Scarlett Johansson sued Disney Thursday, claiming the biggest entertainment company in the world broke its promise to release her latest film “Black Widow” only in movie theaters when it made it available for streaming on the Disney+ video service.

Disney wanted to draw audiences away from movie theaters to its own streaming service to generate revenue, grow subscribers and to devalue Johansson’s contract, the actress said in a complaint.

Disney fired back calling Johansson’s suit “sad and distressing in its callous disregard for the horrific and prolonged global effects of the Covid-19 pandemic.” Read more in our link in bio.

node.text:
Robinhood's public debut wasn't exactly "to the moon" Thursday.

Shortly after opening on the Nasdaq shares slid as much as 11%, but CEO Vlad Tenev says the company is focused on the future, not retail trading volatility.

He told @BloombergTV's @emilychangtv that the future of the company is in more investing options, including expanding its cryptocurrency offerings.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, beard, people standing, footwear, outdoors and text that says '7 Robinhood's co-founders are officially billionaires Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
The stock market debut of Robinhood — whose app drew a new generation of investors into trading on their phones — has cemented its co-founders' spots among America's super-rich. 

Vlad Tenev, 34, and Baiju Bhatt, who's 36, released the first iteration of their app around eight years ago. With Robinhood shares at $38 apiece, CEO Tenev is worth about $2.4 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Bhatt, who shared CEO duties until last year, has a net worth around $2.8 billion. 

Robinhood's IPO marks the pinnacle of a journey that’s helped usher in an era of no-fee stock trading and attracted the scrutiny of regulators. Read in full via the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Nikola founder Trevor Miltonis charged with misleading investors Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The founder and former chairman of Nikola has been charged with making false statements to backers of the electric-vehicle startup.

Trevor Milton, who stepped down from the Tesla competitor last year, is in federal custody after voluntarily surrendering. He's charged with misleading investors from November 2019 until around September 2020 about the development of Nikola’s products and technology. 

The company's shares fell the most in almost five months after the indictment was unsealed. Since June last year, its market cap has plunged from almost $29 billion to about $5 billion. Read the full story via the link in our bio.
